text: NF-kappaB proteins are sequestered in the cytoplasm as latent complexes by inhibitory proteins referred to as inhibitor of NF-kappaB ( IkappaB ) proteins , which prevent NF-kappaB nuclear translocation and DNA binding [ 19 ] .

Whereas the majority of IkappaBs ( <extra_id_0> IkappaBalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IkappaBbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IkappaBepsilon <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> p105 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( also known as <extra_id_0> NF-kappaB1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , <extra_id_0> p100 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( also known as <extra_id_0> NF-kappaB2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) ) serve as inhibitors of NF-kappaB , <extra_id_0> IkappaBxi <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Bcl-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> instead potentiate NF-kappaB transactivation in the nucleus .

<extra_id_0> p100 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p105 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are precursors of the <extra_id_0> p52 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> NF-kappaB subunits , respectively .
There are two unique NF-kappaB signalling pathways , termed canonical ( or classical ) and noncanonical ( or alternative ) NF-kappaB pathways .

The canonical NF-kappaB pathway plays a major role in innate and adaptive immunity , and is triggered by many stimuli including proinflammatory cytokines ( for example , <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , IL-1 ) , antigens , <extra_id_0> RANKL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and TLR ligands .

NF-kappaB signalling initiated by different receptors requires the formation of proximal protein-protein interactions that are often receptor specific , but ultimately converge in the activation of the IkappaB kinase ( IKK ) complex , which mediates phosphorylation of the inhibitory IkappaB protein leading to its K48-polyubiquitination and degradation by the proteasome [ 20 ] .

The IKK complex is comprised of the two catalytic subunits <extra_id_0> IKK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IKK2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( also known as <extra_id_0> IKKalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IKKbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and the regulatory subunit <extra_id_0> NF-kappaB essential modulator <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> NEMO <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - also known as <extra_id_0> IKKgamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) ( Figure 1 ) .

Gene targeting experiments showed that <extra_id_0> IKK2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> NEMO <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , but not <extra_id_0> IKK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , are required for canonical NF-kappaB activation [ 21 ] .
One of the best studied NF-kappaB signalling pathways is the <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> pathway .

<extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> stimulation results in the recruitment of <extra_id_0> TNF receptor-1-associated death domain <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TRADD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) protein and of <extra_id_0> receptor interacting protein 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , which function as adaptor proteins for the E3 ubiquitin ligases <extra_id_0> TNF receptor-associated factor (TRAF) 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> TRAF5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which in turn bind the E3 ubiquitin ligases <extra_id_0> cellular inhibitor of apoptosis (cIAP) 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> cIAP2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( Figure 1 ) .
On <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> stimulation , TNF-receptor bound <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is rapidly modified by K63 - linked polyubiquitin chains .

<extra_id_0> TRAF2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> 5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> cIAP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are good candidates for <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ubiquitination , but the specific role of each is still unclear .

The polyubiquitin chains on <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are believed to create a scaffold to recruit the IKK and <extra_id_0> TAK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> complex via the ubiquitin - binding proteins <extra_id_0> NEMO <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> TAB1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , respectively .

The recent identification of a distinct E2 / E3 enzyme complex that modifies <extra_id_0> NEMO <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> with linear polyubiquitin chains and is essential for <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - activated NF-kappaB signalling adds further complexity [ 22 ] .

The exact role of protein-anchored polyubiquitin chains remains unclear , as it was recently suggested that unanchored polyubiquitin chains can directly activate the <extra_id_0> TAK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> complex [ 23 ] .
Similar signalling principles apply to other receptors .

For example , <extra_id_0> TLR4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> stimulation by lipopolysaccharide induces the recruitment of <extra_id_0> Toll/IL-1 receptor adaptor protein <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( also referred to as <extra_id_0> Ma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> l ) and <extra_id_0> TRIF-related adaptor molecule <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TRAM <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , which most probably serve as bridging factors to recruit <extra_id_0> myeloid differentiation primary response gene 88 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> MyD88 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and <extra_id_0> TIR domain-containing adaptor-inducing IFNbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TRIF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , respectively .

<extra_id_0> MyD88 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in turn recruits members of the IL-1R - associated kinase ( IRAK ) family and <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , leading to oligomerisation and selfubiquitination of <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 24 ] .

<extra_id_0> TRIF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> also recruits <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 25 ] and <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 26 ] via a direct interaction .

Both pathways then activate <extra_id_0> TAK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and IKK in a ubiquitination - dependent manner similar to the <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> pathway ( Figure 1 ) .

The noncanonical NF-kappaB pathway can be activated by the <extra_id_0> lymphotoxin beta receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> BAFF receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> RANK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( Figure 2 ) .

In this pathway , <extra_id_0> p100 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is processed by the proteasome to <extra_id_0> p52 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which together with the <extra_id_0> RelB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> NF-kappaB subunit regulates a distinct set of target genes that control B-cell development , secondary lymphoid organ development , and osteoclastogenesis [ 27 ] The noncanonical NF-kappaB pathway is strictly dependent on <extra_id_0> IKK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which is activated upon phosphorylation by <extra_id_0> NF-kappaB inducing kinase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> NIK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .
<extra_id_0> NIK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is predominantly regulated at the post-translational level and is present at extremely low levels in most cell types .

In unstimulated cells , <extra_id_0> NIK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> occurs in a cytoplasmic complex with <extra_id_0> TRAF2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> TRAF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> cIAP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which K48-polyubiquitinates <extra_id_0> NIK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , leading to its continuous degradation by the proteasome .

Receptor ligation has been shown not only to remove <extra_id_0> TRAF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> from this complex by recruiting it to the receptor , but also to attract <extra_id_0> TRAF2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> cIAP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which are essential for subsequent <extra_id_0> TRAF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> degradation .

All this contributes to releasing <extra_id_0> NIK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> from its constitutive degradation , resulting in <extra_id_0> NIK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> accumulation and <extra_id_0> IKK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phosphorylation [ 28 , 29 ] ( Figure 2 ) .

It should be mentioned that <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> lymphotoxin beta receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> RANK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mediate the activation of both canonical and noncanonical NF-kappaB signalling pathways .

Upon binding of their ligand , <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> RANK <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> interact with several TRAF members , including <extra_id_0> TRAF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> TRAF2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> TRAF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> TRAF5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and this leads to the proteolysis of both <extra_id_0> TRAF2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> TRAF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which represents an important step in the activation of the noncanonical pathway as described above .
Specific TRAF molecules are associated with overlapping and distinct <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated functions .

For example , in B cells <extra_id_0> TRAF6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is required for <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated JNK activation and <extra_id_0> IL-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production , while <extra_id_0> TRAF2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is required for activation of NF-kappaB , and <extra_id_0> TRAF3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> serves as a negative regulator of <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signalling [ 30 , 31 ] .
